snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you for this Video. I ‘build’ servers for small companies. I have a long standing argument with a client. They are convinced that the answer to their performance issues is to throw hardware at bad code. While it sucks you had to go through this exercise, it will save us in the wider world. I can now say, “More power; more NvME; more PCI” is not the answer you are looking for.

Thank you! And thank your community of experts.
snippet.textOriginal:
Thank you for this Video. I ‘build’ servers for small companies. I have a long standing argument with a client.  They are convinced that the answer to their performance issues is to throw hardware at bad code.  While it sucks you had to go through this exercise, it will save us in the wider world. I can now say, “More power; more NvME; more PCI” is not the answer you are looking for. 

Thank you! And thank your community of experts.

snippet.textDisplay:
What about a Linux Real-Time Kernel? That's "commonly" done when data channels need to continually feed data.

For example, there's a CNC Control System called "Path Pilot" that runs on Linux with a Real-Time Kernel so that there is a FAR lower potential for losing data transfer rates from the hard drive/memory off to the CNC Machine.
snippet.textOriginal:
What about a Linux Real-Time Kernel? That's "commonly" done when data channels need to continually feed data.

For example, there's a CNC Control System called "Path Pilot" that runs on Linux with a Real-Time Kernel so that there is a FAR lower potential for losing data transfer rates from the hard drive/memory off to the CNC Machine.

snippet.textDisplay: Try use fewer and faster cpu cores... this is a constant issue we see in very large hypervisor environments, with vm's that uses many cores, especially if they are to handle network traffic, like firewalls.

snippet.textDisplay:
So, if core switching occurs as part of the normal process, why isn't attached process such as interupts also looked at and switched to a suitable core if required - or - if that isn't / couldn't be done then why isn't core switching prevented (for that core) if that core has an unmoveable IRQ attached?
It just seems as if the switching management method is...a little dumb??
snippet.textOriginal:
So, if core switching occurs as part of the normal process, why isn't attached process such as interupts also looked at and switched to a suitable core if required - or - if that isn't / couldn't be done then why isn't core switching prevented (for that core) if that core has an unmoveable IRQ attached? 
It just seems as if the switching management method is...a little dumb??

snippet.textDisplay:
While I understand your need to get something working, polling is never a good idea. It is because you are polling and not using the interrupts that you're burning up all those CPU cycles. That's what polling does, waste CPU cycles.

The problem is not that this system is so blazingly-fast that the H/W is not capable of keeping up. While parts of this configuration may be capable of speeds that other H/W cannot support, the worse that should happen is that your throughput should be limited by the slowest link in the chain. Trust someone who has been writing H/W drivers and interrupt handlers for 30+ years, your CPU is not missing interrupts because it's not powerful enough. The problem is you have one or more poorly written drivers that this blazingly-fast configuration has exposed.

It is those drivers that are not correctly handling interrupts. Why do you see issues in Linux and Windows? Most probably because those driver writers wrote the drivers for both operating systems and used much of the same flawed code. By switching to polling you have simply avoided the problem and settled for increased CPU usage and a decrease in maximum performance. You should file a bug with Microsoft and your Linux provider if you'd like to ever see this fixed.

snippet.textDisplay: I have to wonder if the outcome would be different with hardware raid cards versus hba’s and software raid? My train of thought with hardware raid is that the card would handle the communication with then drives on its own bus, free’ing up pcie to handle actual data transfer instead of constantly polling. This is assuming the hba just makes the drives available as individual devices on the pcie bus. I am almost certain the hardware raid card hides the individual drive from the bus and the card becomes the drive, fewer addressable devices seems like a good thing in this case. The hardware offload for parity and other calculations is just gravy on top.
snippet.textOriginal: I have to wonder if the outcome would be different with hardware raid cards versus hba’s and software raid? My train of thought with hardware raid is that the card would handle the communication with then drives on its own bus, free’ing up pcie to handle actual data transfer instead of constantly polling. This is assuming the hba just makes the drives available as individual devices on the pcie bus. I am almost certain the hardware raid card hides the individual drive from the bus and the card becomes the drive, fewer addressable devices seems like a good thing in this case. The hardware offload for parity and other calculations is just gravy on top.

snippet.textDisplay:
Interesting ... while much more remote in nature, on the mainframe under MVS storage controllers featured multipath access with I/O completion able to respond on any dispatchable engine (CPU).

Of course, I/O rates were much lower, but architecturally this didn't require that the initiating engine be idle when I/O completion was posted.

My experience with this stuff was quite some time ago with much more expensive machines, but a lot of the current service ideas came from the mainframe, though a lot of it never made to the current server architectures like the ability to set flags indicating that the current I/O is for a backup to prevent the storage controller from poisoning its cache.
snippet.textOriginal:
Interesting ... while much more _remote_ in nature, on the mainframe under MVS storage controllers featured multipath access with I/O completion able to respond on any dispatchable engine (CPU).

Of course, I/O rates were much lower, but architecturally this didn't require that the initiating engine be idle when I/O completion was posted.

My experience with this stuff was quite some time ago with much more expensive machines, but a lot of the current service ideas came from the mainframe, though a lot of it never made to the current server architectures like the ability to set flags indicating that the current I/O is for a backup to prevent the storage controller from poisoning its cache.

snippet.textDisplay: Task split between two blades with 50% the number of drives in each with a dedicated mid process server between them and you main server.  It would allow for more parallel level access instead of all this sequential bottle necking.  Two smaller blades would better interact with each other  in much the same way as active short and long term memory does.
snippet.textOriginal: Task split between two blades with 50% the number of drives in each with a dedicated mid process server between them and you main server.  It would allow for more parallel level access instead of all this sequential bottle necking.  Two smaller blades would better interact with each other  in much the same way as active short and long term memory does.

snippet.textDisplay: Short of it is , shader cache is written to ssd! !  Given what you ask of the whole thing ? flushing the cache is likely a huge problem but I could be wrong ! But given the behavior you are noticing ? It sound oddly very similar to what gamer had problem with the way nvidia cache handle thing ! maybe turn the shader cache off and let window or linux handle things?
snippet.textOriginal: Short of it is , shader cache is written to ssd! !  Given what you ask of the whole thing ? flushing the cache is likely a huge problem but I could be wrong ! It sound oddly very similar to what gamer had problem with the way nvidia cache handle thing ! maybe turn the shader cache off and let window or linux handle things?

snippet.textDisplay: You do know that nvidia do cache flush very frequently right ? have you tried one that is not nvidia and does not do the stupid nvidia cache flush? To see if this is what cause the issue ! last I checked doing cache flush will make OS basicly start from scratch ! Given how much data you want to make flow ? only thing that come to mind is the nvidia cache flush !

snippet.textDisplay:
So this was super interesting as it exposes an issue that we're currently dealing with in the Enterprise storage space. I think poor Linus had to fall down the rabbit hole to discover an issue that has been here since day one of NVMe, and that is that current operating system storage subsystems and file-systems were not designed to handle SSD's (SATA or SAS NAND flash), and completely unprepared to handle PCIe attached NAND flash.

The reason that we don't see the same behavior when we use SAS or SATA SSD's is that the SSD's in those cases are still behind some sort of storage controller, which is often still handling RAID calculations but even if you're using software RAID or erasure coding, the storage controller is the bottleneck and protects the rest of the system from being flogged and overrun. To further protect the system, SAS and SATA SSD's force NAND flash to operate on a serial storage subsystem, effectively a modern derivative of old school SCSI, which has been around for eons. Flash does not like being treated like a spinning SCSI device, which is why a given set of flash chips in a drive on a SAS interface might top out at 600 MB/s throughput and 50,000 IOPs, but those same chip's directly attached to a PCIe bus could in theory drive 5000MB/s and 500,000 IOPs. Much of the challenge here is latency, where SSD's attached to a SAS controller might have a latency of 500ns, on the PCIe bus that latency could be as low as 100ns or lower (.1 milliseconds) Modern OS's have adapted a little bit to be able to handle one, maybe two NVMe devices fairly well, but when you attempt to communicate with 5, 10 or 20 NVMe devices concurrently, it tends to all fall apart. The OS storage subsystem simply can't use the traditional method of creating a stripe, write to multiple devices, check checksum, calculate XOR, write parity and validate while preparing the next stripe. Also, without using a storage controller, there is no dedicated device controlling the flow off traffic to/from each storage device, which while slow, they're pretty good at doing so. Instead the CPU and OS subsystem are forced to attempt to do this, and when coupled with the fact that the combined NVMe bandwidth can easily overwhelm even the fastest memory subsystem, you now have multiple challenges that traditional compute architectures struggle to overcome.

One other factor that Linus discovered is that of the relationships between CPU processing threads and PCIe device IO interrupts. The PCI bus may have multiple hardware lanes but it's still by a shared highway designed to give somewhat equal access to each device. A single device IO is usually tied to a single CPU hardware thread, and on a system with many PCIe lanes/devices and a processor with tons of hardware threads (cores), this normally results in fairly balanced and scalable performance. This goes out the window when a single NVMe device is more than what a single thread can handle, made worse by slower hardware threads and even worse by trying to run multiple threads per core. Adding more fuel to the fire is CPU scheduling, where modern CPU's work very hard to always do things in the most efficient manner possible.

Right now, when I'm planning an NVMe storage platform, I have some best practices I follow to reduce the occurrence of these issues. First, I ensure that the processor has fast cores (I'll choose 16 x 4GHz cores rather than 32 x 2GHz cores).
Second, I disable hyperthreading so that a hardware thread is a hardware core.
3rd, I do not exceed the PCIe lanes, either in total or per slot. If I have a Gen 3 PCIe x16 slot, I put no more than four gen3 x4 NVMe devices on it, preferably three.
4th, I leave enough cores for the OS and enough remaining PCIe lanes for other devices, like NICs, HBA's and even BMC interconnects.
5th, I get the fastest memory, lowest timings configured in the fastest DIMM module layout for that system (usually single rank). So in actual practice, I might take a dual socket 32-core high clockspeed system, set aside 4 cores per socket for the OS and other system components and functions leaving just 24 non hyperthreaded cores for PCIe devices, and maybe 12 or 24 single rank 16GB DIMMs.
6th, write caching is usually your enemy in NVMe storage as it overloads the memory interconnects, disable any kind of write caching, multiple NVMe devices likely don't need write caching anyway and even read caching effectiveness is questionable.
Depending on the architecture and PCIe lane availability (48 x gen3 for Xeon scalable), I might only size for 8 x gen3 x4 NVMe devices, spread evenly across each CPUs PCIe buses.
Lastly, traditional RAID does not scale with NVMe, especially RAID 5 or RAID 6 where parity must be calculated for each stripe, then written. The amount of processing required for parity calcs at NVMe speeds destroys even the best processors, even the best specialized RAID controller processors. It sounds crazy, expensive and wasteful, but using simple mirrored pairs and then striping across the pairs provides the least overhead, as parity doesn't have to be calculated. This means that the OS only needs to incur the overhead of splitting a write into two and writing it to two devices. Simple volume striping on top is also lower overhead. So as you can imagine, this example system with 8 x 4TB PCIe gen3 NVMe devices when configured using simple mirroring and volume striping is now only providing about 15TiB of usable capacity. The upside is that write performance will likely be just about 1/2 of read performance and fairly consistent and predictable.

As you can see, NVMe has been both a blessing and a curse. Current computing platforms and operating systems were not designed to be capable of effectively handling NVMe at scale. This is why guys like Andy Bechtolsheim created DSSD (which got bought and basically killed by EMC). He understood many of these challenges working with early PCIe flash devices at Sun and subsequently Oracle. It'll be interesting to see how the industry evolves to solve for these challenges.
/end wall of text


EDIT One more note... Windows storage spaces sucks, and everything I talked about above is just for back-end storage performance and doesn't even deal with client connection access challenges if it's a file server.

So in actual practice, I might take a dual socket 32-core high clockspeed system, set aside 4 cores per socket for the OS and other system components and functions leaving just 24 non hyperthreaded cores for PCIe devices, and maybe 12 or 24 single rank 16GB DIMMs. 
6th, write caching is usually your enemy in NVMe storage as it overloads the memory interconnects, disable any kind of write caching, multiple NVMe devices likely don't need write caching anyway and even read caching effectiveness is questionable.
Depending on the architecture and PCIe lane availability (48 x gen3 for Xeon scalable), I might only size for 8 x gen3 x4 NVMe devices, spread evenly across each CPUs PCIe buses.
Lastly, traditional RAID does not scale with NVMe, especially RAID 5 or RAID 6 where parity must be calculated for each stripe, then written. The amount of processing required for parity calcs at NVMe speeds destroys even the best processors, even the best specialized RAID controller processors. It sounds crazy, expensive and wasteful, but using simple mirrored pairs and then striping across the pairs provides the least overhead, as parity doesn't have to be calculated. This means that the OS only needs to incur the overhead of splitting a write into two and writing it to two devices. Simple volume striping on top is also lower overhead. So as you can imagine, this example system with 8 x 4TB PCIe gen3 NVMe devices when configured using simple mirroring and volume striping is now only providing about 15TiB of usable capacity. The upside is that write performance will likely be just about 1/2 of read performance and fairly consistent and predictable. 

As you can see, NVMe has been both a blessing and a curse. Current computing platforms and operating systems were not designed to be capable of effectively handling NVMe at scale. This is why guys like Andy Bechtolsheim created DSSD (which got bought and basically killed by EMC). He understood many of these challenges working with early PCIe flash devices at Sun and subsequently Oracle. It'll be interesting to see how the industry evolves to solve for these challenges.
/end wall of text


*EDIT* One more note... Windows storage spaces sucks, and everything I talked about above is just for back-end storage performance and doesn't even deal with client connection access challenges if it's a file server.
